speaker: Elizabeth Warren
vclaim: "The law states that mental health must be treated like physical health," but coverage by health insurance companies is uneven.
date: stated on July 11, 2019 in a public forum:
title: Warren refers to disparities in physical and mental health insurance coverage
text: :: During a visit to Milwaukee in July, Elizabeth Warren, President of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, who is hopeful to the public, said that when it comes to their mental health needs, their health insurance may not always be on their side. According to Senator Massachusetts, there is an unequal playing field when it comes to covering physical and mental health needs. Warren says at the League of Latin American Citizens United Conference in Milwaukee on July 11, 2019, that health providers are not equally interested in both. Warren was among eight democratic presidential competitors, in addition to Jill Biden, wife of candidate Joe Biden, who attended the conference. The Association is the largest and oldest Spanish civil rights organization in the country. But what does the law say about physical versus mental health? As Warren claims, are insurance companies treating them unequally? When we reached Warren's support campaign, his spokesman, Chris Hayden, told us that the senator was referring to the basic health benefits of the Affordable Care Act. The Anti-Corruption Act required small and individual market plans to cover 10 different categories of benefits, including maternity and newborn care, ambulance services, emergency services and prescription drugs. Mental health services and substance abuse disorders have also been included as benefits. Hayden also referred to the law on equal mental health and equitable addiction, sponsored by Senators Paul Willston and Pete Dominci, which was enacted in October 2008. The law requires equal coverage for the treatment of mental illness and addiction. In accordance with the National Alliance on Mental Diseases, the Federal Government issued rules for the implementation of the Act in November 2013. Before the law, mental health treatment was usually covered by lower levels in health insurance policies for physical illness. Therefore, Warren ' s position that the law requires equal insurance coverage for mental and physical health is verified. But is there a disparity in the way insurance companies serve patients for these needs? By Haley Bimeler: 26 January 2021 A 2017 National Study by Meleman, an actuarial health-care consulting firm, patients often use an off-line service provider for behavioural and mental health services much more than physical health needs. The study concluded that the probability of providing behavioural care in 2015 was four to six times greater than that of providing out-of-net medical or surgical care, and that insurance companies paid primary care providers 20 per cent for the same types of care as addiction and mental health care workers. In Wisconsin, about 13% of office visits to behavioural health were off-line compared to 2.5% for primary care. This confirms that the insurance network did not include a similar number of physicians providing mental health care. According to the Kaiser Health News newspaper on 3 August 2015, since the entry into force of the Mental Health Equality Act, most insurance companies have made progress in their coverage of mental health, such as dropping annual restrictions on treatment sessions, increasing joint payments, and separating mental health discounts from cases. However, Caesar also reports that insurance companies have continued to limit treatment through other methods, such as enforcing a "medical necessity" review of patients in some cases. In those reviews, insurers - not doctors - decide whether and how frequently a patient needs specific treatment. In addition, only a few states have verified whether insurance companies comply with the parity laws, and the United States Government has taken no public enforcement action against an insurance company or employer for violation of the law since its promulgation, according to Kaiser ' s report. In states such as New York, Illinois and California, where patients faced problems with their mental health coverage, legal proceedings were instituted against insurance companies. Warren claimed that mental and physical health should be treated in the same way under the law, but coverage by health insurance companies is uneven. The Law on Equal Mental Health and Equitable Addictions stipulates that insured persons must provide equal coverage of physical and mental health. The Anti-Corruption Act provided that insurance companies should cover certain benefits that included behavioural health.
